Award.AbstractNarration:
This grant is to fund the 32nd annual Workshop in Geometric Topology, to be hosted at Texas Christian University in Fort Worth, Texas, June 25-27, 2015, as well as the 33rd and 34th workshops in 2016 and 2017, to be hosted by Colorado College and Brigham Young University. Such mathematics workshops provide an opportunity for mathematicians working in a certain subfield, in this case geometric topology, to meet, interact, and share their research through both official lecture presentations and informal discussions. Grant funds will be utilized primarily to support the travel and attendance costs of conference participants, particularly graduate students, young Ph.D.s, and other researchers without their own sources of funding.
The field of geometric topology, broadly speaking, is the study of spatial configuration, both in the physical universe and of abstract "spaces" that can model real-life phenomena. For example, a topologist might study how a physical string or protein strand is knotted in the real three-dimensional world, or he or she might study the abstract space of positions that a machine could inhabit, allowing for an arbitrary number of parameters that describe the positions of various components. Research in this field can vary from the highly abstract to more concrete applications supported by those abstract underpinnings. Modern applications of topology occur in such diverse areas as robot motion planning, data analysis, image processing, sensor networks, and mathematical biology.


A primary goal of these Workshops in Geometric Topology is to provide mathematicians in geometric topology (and, more recently, the closely related field of geometric group theory) who have active research programs, but limited support, an opportunity to discuss their work with others in the field. Another important goal is to expand the interests of the participants by having a nationally-recognized expert discuss an important area of current interest. A third goal is to provide a serious but informal research atmosphere in which graduate students can meet and learn from others in the field. At each workshop, participants will have the opportunity to attend three lectures given by a principal speakers chosen for his or her top-tier research credentials and superb expository abilities. The principal speaker at the 32nd annual Workshop will be the internationally-renowned Wolfgang LÃ¼ck of the University of Bonn and the Hausdorff Research Institute for Mathematics; he will provide introductory talks about L2-Betti numbers and the Farrell-Jones Conjecture and then a talk about applications to 3-manifolds. The other workshop participants will be invited to share their own work by giving short talks in a congenial environment, and important time will be provided for informal discussion and interaction among participants and with the principal speaker. Overall, the workshops will provide opportunities for geometric topologists to interact and share ideas, leading to possible research collaborations. The workshops will be advertised nationally. Graduate students and members of underrepresented groups will be given top priority for funding and will be particularly encouraged to attend and to speak. The website for the 32nd annual workshop can be found at http://faculty.tcu.edu/gfriedman/GTW2015/

POR.DRECONTENT:
NSF Grant DMS-1461385 funded the annual "Workshops in Geometric Topology" in the years 2015-2017; a no-cost extension allowed some unspent funds to help with the 2018 workshop as well. Nearly all funding was used to cover travel expenses of workshop participants, with most going to participants without other means of support. Graduate students and recent graduates as well as members of underrepresented groups were given special consideration for funding.

 

The Geometric Topology Workshops provide an annual opportunity for active researchers and graduate students to interact in a setting that provides multiple tangible benefits, including:  attending the lectures of the principal speaker to receive an in-depth introduction to important current streams of research being performed by nationally recognized experts; learning about a breadth of other research activities by attending shorter talks given by the other workshop participants; the opportunity to share their own work by giving talks in a congenial environment; and important time for informal discussion and interaction among participants and with the principal speaker. To further broaden the impact of the workshops, most of the talks of principal speakers are recorded and posted to the internet.

 

Texas Christian University hosted the 2015 Workshop, which was held on their campus in Fort Worth, TX. Wolfgang Lueck of the University of Bonn and the Hausdorff Research Institute for Mathematics delivered the principal lectures on several different topics in geometric topology, including L2 invariants, the Farrell-Jones Conjecture, and applications to 3-manifolds. Among the 42 mathematicians attending the conference were 17 graduate students and 5 postdocs. In addition to Lueck's lectures, there were 22 twenty-minute talks contributed by other workshop participants; 3 of those were by postdocs and 13 by graduate students.

 

Colorado College hosted the 2016 workshop, which was held on their campus in Colorado Springs. Nathan Dunfield of the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign delivered the principal lectures on various areas of low-dimensional topology including finite covers of 3-manifolds, norms on cohomology, and Floer homology, group orders, and taut foliations of hyperbolic 3-manifolds. Among the 33 mathematicians attending the conference were 8 students and 3 postdocs. There were 21 twenty-minute talks contributed by other workshop participants of which 3 were given by students and 3 by postdocs.

 

Brigham Young University hosted the 2017 workshop, which was held in Provo, UT. Moon Duchin of Tufts University lectured on topics of geometric group theory, including nilpotent groups, growth series and rationality, and the geometry of words. Among the 30 mathematicians attending the conference were 10 graduate students. There were 19 contributed talks, of which 8 were given by graduate students and 3 by recent PhDs.

 

Calvin College hosted the 2018 Workshop, which was held on their campus in Grand Rapids, Michigan. Andras Stipsicz of the Alfred Renyi Institute of Mathematics in Budapest, Hungary, delivered the principal lectures on invariants of knots and links. Among the 55 mathematicians attending the conference were 17 graduate students, 2 postdocs, and 3 undergraduate students. 23 contributed talks of twenty-minutes were given, 8 by students and 2 by postdocs.

 

An archive of materials from past workshops can be found at http://faculty.tcu.edu/gfriedman/GTW_archive/ .
